caseTitle: CHAPEL HILL SCHOOL LTD. V AG COMM OF IRS
summary: The Supreme Court of Ghana ruled that Chapel Hill School Ltd., prior to its conversion into a company limited by shares in 2001, was an educational institution of a public character and therefore entitled to tax exemption on its income. The court dismissed a review application brought by the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, affirming its earlier decision. The applicant sought review under article 133 of the Constitution and rule 54 of the Supreme Court Rules, alleging exceptional circumstances and miscarriage of justice. The court reaffirmed that review is not an appellate remedy but a special jurisdiction exercisable only in cases of fundamental error, per incuriam decisions, or grave injustice. It held that the original decision correctly interpreted the law and that no grounds for review existed.
verdict: Application for review dismissed; original decision upholding tax exemption affirmed.
citations: In re Assessment of Income Tax by The Commissioner of Internal Revenue; Chapel Hill School v Attorney-General & Internal Revenue Service (2009) SC GLR 432
Quartey v Central Services Co. Ltd. (1996-97) SC GLR 398
Afranie II v Qaurcoo (1992)2 GLR 561 S.C
Republic v. High Court Kumasi Ex Parte Abubakari (No. 3)[2000] SC GLR 45
rationaleHighlights: Chapel Hill School was deemed an educational institution of public character prior to conversion into a company limited by shares
Income of such institutions is exempt from taxation under Ghanaian law
Review applications require exceptional circumstances or discovery of new evidence
A fundamental legal error resulting in miscarriage of justice justifies review
Misconstruction of statutory provisions may deprive court of jurisdiction
